Cheesy Bacon Potato Skins

Jump to Recipe

If you're looking for a delicious appetizer or snack that packs a punch of flavor, look no further than these Cheesy Bacon Potato Skins! This classic dish is a favorite at parties, game days, or even as a comforting treat at home. Made with crispy, golden russet potatoes, topped with gooey cheddar cheese, savory crumbled bacon, and finished off with a dollop of creamy sour cream and fresh green onions, these potato skins are sure to delight your taste buds. Not only are they easy to prepare, but they also allow you to customize the toppings to suit your preferences. Whether you’re hosting a gathering or just craving something indulgent, Cheesy Bacon Potato Skins offer the perfect combination of crunchy, cheesy, and smoky goodness. In this article, we'll guide you through each step of the cooking process, ensuring that you create potato skins that are crispy on the outside and loaded with flavor on the inside. Get ready to impress your family and friends with this irresistible recipe!

Ingredients

russet potatoes

Choose firm, unblemished russet potatoes for the best texture. If you're short on time, you can microwave them instead of baking, but for the best flavor and crispiness, stick to the oven. For a healthier alternative, you can use sweet potatoes.

cheddar cheese, shredded

Opt for sharp cheddar for a stronger flavor, but feel free to mix with other cheeses like Monterey Jack or Pepper Jack for added creaminess or spice. If you want a lighter option, use a reduced-fat cheese.

cooked bacon, crumbled

Use thick-cut bacon for added texture and flavor. Turkey bacon can be a lower-fat substitute; just make sure to crisp it up well. For a vegetarian option, consider using crumbled tempeh or mushrooms sautéed with smoked paprika.

sour cream

Sour cream adds creaminess; Greek yogurt can be a healthier substitute with similar tanginess. Consider flavored sour cream (like onion or garlic) for an added kick.

green onions, chopped

Use fresh green onions for a mild onion flavor; if unavailable, chives can be a good substitute. For a different taste, try using diced jalapeños for a spicy twist.

olive oil

Extra virgin olive oil will provide the best flavor; however, canola or avocado oil can be used as alternatives. For added flavor, infuse your olive oil with garlic or herbs before brushing onto the potatoes.

salt

Use kosher salt for better texture and flavor distribution. If you're watching sodium, consider sea salt or a salt substitute, but adjust to taste.

black pepper

Freshly ground black pepper will give the best flavor. If you want a spicier kick, try using white pepper or a dash of cayenne pepper.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Preheat the Oven

    Start by preheating your oven to 400°F (200°C). This ensures that your potatoes will cook evenly and thoroughly.

  • Step 2: Prepare the Potatoes

    Wash and scrub 4 large russet potatoes thoroughly under running water to remove any dirt. Prick each potato several times with a fork to allow steam to escape during baking. Rub the potatoes with 2 tablespoons of olive oil and season with 1 teaspoon of salt and 1/2 teaspoon of black pepper.

  • Step 3: Bake the Potatoes

    Place the prepared potatoes directly on the oven rack. Bake for about 45 minutes or until they are tender when pierced with a fork. To check for doneness, insert a fork into the center; it should slide in easily.

  • Step 4: Cool the Potatoes

    Once baked, remove the potatoes from the oven and let them cool for about 10 minutes. This makes them easier to handle.

  • Step 5: Scoop Out the Insides

    Carefully cut each potato in half lengthwise. Use a spoon to scoop out some of the insides, creating a hollow skin. Leave a little potato for texture and to help support the skin.

  • Step 6: Season the Skins

    Brush the inside of each potato skin with a little more olive oil and sprinkle with salt and pepper to enhance the flavor.

  • Step 7: Fill the Skins

    Place the potato skins cut side up on a baking sheet. Fill each skin with 1 cup of shredded cheddar cheese and 1/2 cup of crumbled cooked bacon.

  • Step 8: Bake Again

    Return the filled potato skins to the oven and bake for an additional 10-15 minutes, or until the cheese is melted and bubbly.

  • Step 9: Add Toppings and Serve

    Remove from the oven and top each potato skin with 1/2 cup of sour cream and 1/4 cup of chopped green onions. Serve warm and enjoy!

Frequently Asked Questions

How do I properly wash and prepare the potatoes?

To wash the potatoes, scrub them under cold water with a vegetable brush to remove any dirt. After washing, be sure to dry them thoroughly before cooking.

What is the best way to prick the potatoes?

Use a fork to prick the potatoes several times all over. This allows steam to escape while baking, preventing them from bursting in the oven.

How can I tell when the potatoes are done baking?

The potatoes are done when they feel soft when squeezed gently (use an oven mitt) and a fork can easily pierce through them. This usually takes about 45 minutes at 400°F.

How do I scoop out the potato without breaking the skin?

Use a spoon to carefully scoop out the insides of the potato, leaving about 1/4 inch of potato around the edges. Take your time to avoid tearing the skin.

Can I use different types of cheese?

Absolutely! You can use mozzarella, gouda, or even a blend of your favorite cheeses. Just make sure they melt well.

What if I don't have olive oil?

You can substitute olive oil with other oils such as vegetable oil or melted butter. Each will add a slightly different flavor.

How can I make sure my bacon is crispy?

For crispy bacon, bake it in the oven or fry it in a pan until it's golden brown and crispy. Let it drain on paper towels to remove excess grease.

What can I serve with potato skins?

Potato skins are great on their own, but you can serve them with additional dips like ranch dressing or a side salad to balance the meal.

How do I safely handle hot potatoes?

Always use oven mitts to handle hot potatoes and let them cool for a few minutes before cutting them. This reduces the risk of burns.

Can I make these potato skins ahead of time?

Yes! You can prepare the potato skins up to the filling stage, refrigerate them, and bake them when you're ready to serve.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

For a gluten-free version, ensure that all ingredients, particularly the bacon and any sauces, are certified gluten-free. To make the dish vegetarian, consider replacing the bacon with sautéed mushrooms or smoked tempeh for a similar savory flavor. For a lighter option, use low-fat cheese and sour cream, or substitute Greek yogurt for sour cream to reduce calories while boosting protein content.

Pairings

For a delightful pairing with Cheesy Bacon Potato Skins, consider serving them with a classic American lager or a light pilsner, which will complement the rich flavors without overpowering them. If you prefer a non-alcoholic option, a sparkling apple cider or a refreshing lemonade would work beautifully. For a meatier touch, pair the skins with grilled chicken or BBQ ribs, as the smoky flavors will enhance the savory profile of the dish.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the Cheesy Bacon Potato Skins hot out of the oven on a rustic wooden platter for a casual gathering. Offer a variety of dipping sauces alongside, such as ranch dressing, spicy sriracha mayo, or a zesty guacamole, to add an extra layer of flavor. Garnish with additional chopped green onions and a sprinkle of paprika for a pop of color. For a more formal occasion, plate the skins individually on small appetizer plates with a side of sour cream for dipping, creating an elegant presentation.

Cheesy Bacon Potato Skins

45 min
$10
400 kcal
Difficulty: 30%
Servings: 4

Allergens:

DairyPork

Dietary Tags:

Vegetarian-FriendlyGluten-Free Option

AppetizerSnack

Tags:

AppetizerSnackComfort Food

Description

Crispy potato halves loaded with melted cheese and crispy bacon, perfect for snacking or as a side dish!

Ingredients

  • russet potatoes: 4 large
  • cheddar cheese, shredded: 1 cup
  • cooked bacon, crumbled: 1/2 cup
  • sour cream: 1/2 cup
  • green onions, chopped: 1/4 cup
  • olive oil: 2 tablespoons
  • salt: 1 teaspoon
  • black pepper: 1/2 teaspoon
